intro: Leptosiphon serrulatus, commonly known as the narrow-leaf bluebell, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Fabaceae family, characterized by its compound leaves and pod-like fruits. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is adapted to arid environments. Its flowers are small, blue to purple, and bloom in spring, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Leptosiphon serrulatus is often found in scrubland and chaparral habitats, where it plays a role in stabilizing soil and supporting local biodiversity.
